lines.text: Enter HELENA and Clown

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: My mother greets me kindly; is she well?

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: She is not well; but yet she has her health: she's very merry; but yet she is not well: but thanks be given, she's very well and wants nothing i', the world; but yet she is not well.

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: If she be very well, what does she ail, that she's not very well?

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Truly, she's very well indeed, but for two things.

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: What two things?

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: One, that she's not in heaven, whither God send her quickly! the other that she's in earth, from whence God send her quickly!
Enter PAROLLES

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Bless you, my fortunate lady!

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: I hope, sir, I have your good will to have mine own good fortunes.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: You had my prayers to lead them on; and to keep them on, have them still. O, my knave, how does my old lady?

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: So that you had her wrinkles and I her money, I would she did as you say.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Why, I say nothing.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Marry, you are the wiser man; for many a man's tongue shakes out his master's undoing: to say nothing, to do nothing, to know nothing, and to have nothing, is to be a great part of your title; which is within a very little of nothing.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Away! thou'rt a knave.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: You should have said, sir, before a knave thou'rt a knave; that's, before me thou'rt a knave: this had been truth, sir.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Go to, thou art a witty fool; I have found thee.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Did you find me in yourself, sir? or were you taught to find me? The search, sir, was profitable; and much fool may you find in you, even to the world's pleasure and the increase of laughter.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: A good knave, i' faith, and well fed. Madam, my lord will go away to-night; A very serious business calls on him. The great prerogative and rite of love, Which, as your due, time claims, he does acknowledge; But puts it off to a compell'd restraint; Whose want, and whose delay, is strew'd with sweets, Which they distil now in the curbed time, To make the coming hour o'erflow with joy And pleasure drown the brim.

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: What's his will else?

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: That you will take your instant leave o' the king And make this haste as your own good proceeding, Strengthen'd with what apology you think May make it probable need.

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: What more commands he?

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: That, having this obtain'd, you presently Attend his further pleasure.

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: In every thing I wait upon his will.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: I shall report it so.

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: I pray you. Come, sirrah.
Exit PAROLLES
Exeunt
